title: 107_hr2645
content: The Motor Donor Act, also known as the National Organ Donor Registry, amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a national organ donor registry. The purposes of this subpart are to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, enhance information provided to individuals, ensure accurate information on donation wishes, and provide grants to establish donor registries. The subpart aims to increase organ and tissue donor registrations by establishing a national registry linked to state motor vehicle driver's license applications. The registry will provide grants to states for this purpose and maintain a database of donor information. The Secretary will establish a national organ and tissue donor registry, consisting of individual information and a unique identification number. Coordination with states and organ procurement organizations will be conducted during the initial 2-year period after the enactment of the Motor Donor Act. During the initial 2-year period after the Motor Donor Act, the Secretary will coordinate with states to share data from organ and tissue donor registries. Links will be provided between the national Registry and State agencies. During the 4-year period after the Motor Donor Act, the Secretary will coordinate with states to establish organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. Organ procurement organizations will have 24-hour access to the Registry using a password assigned by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide organ procurement organizations with 24-hour access to the Registry using a password. A pamphlet containing information on organ and tissue donations will be disseminated to US citizens who filed a Federal income tax return in the prior year. Following the Motor Donor Act, the Secretary will distribute a pamphlet to US citizens who filed a Federal income tax return the previous year, containing information on organ and tissue donations. Individuals can elect to participate in the Registry through a website address provided in the pamphlet. Participation in the Registry does not impact organ or tissue allocation practices. The Registry notifies individuals about their participation, without affecting organ allocation. It serves as an intent registry for organ donation, not legally binding consent. Participants can cancel their registration. The Registry serves as an intent registry for organ donation, not legally binding consent. Participants can cancel their registration at any time. The Secretary will notify individuals of their right to cancel and promptly remove their information from the Registry. The Secretary will remove information from the Registry for individuals who cancel participation. Grants are awarded to States for implementing State registries linked to the driver's license application process. States must submit applications to the Secretary for grant consideration. Each State seeking a grant for organ and tissue donation programs must submit an application to the Secretary outlining procedures for individuals to make legally binding gifts. The application must also include assurances that the State will establish these procedures. Each State seeking a grant for organ and tissue donation programs must submit an application to the Secretary outlining procedures for individuals to make legally binding gifts, including designating donation preferences on a motor vehicle driver's license application. The application must also include assurances that the State will comply with specific requirements for the process. The State motor vehicle authority application allows individuals to designate their intent to be an organ and tissue donor. The application must include a question about organ donor designation in the State registry or on the driver's license. The State procedures require individuals to answer affirmatively to have their organ donor preference noted in the State registry or on their driver's license. The State agency provides 24-hour access to donor information to organ procurement organizations without fees. The Secretary prioritizes grants for States collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded to a State cannot exceed $300,000. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation is established. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, called the Task Force, consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience with organ or tissue donations and procurement. No grant awarded to a State under this subsection shall exceed $300,000. The Secretary appoints members of the Task Force based on their experience with organ or tissue donations, procurement, or transplants. At least one member must be a physician with transplant experience, and another must have organ procurement experience. Each member serves a term unless specified otherwise. Terms of two initial members expire after 2 years. Vacancies do not affect the Task Force's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation for a national awareness campaign and must submit a report within 1 year. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation for a national awareness campaign and must submit a report within 1 year on improving the Registry, increasing public awareness about organ and tissue donation, and improving the donation process. Amounts appropriated will remain available until expended. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT OF INTERNAL REVENUE CODE. Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer identification information to the Department of Health and Human Services for the organ donor program. The disclosed information can only be used for this specific purpose. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer information to the Department of Health and Human Services for the organ donor program, with restrictions on the use of the disclosed information for contacting individuals regarding the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378, by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
